awd_titl_txt: Expanding the Network of STEM Scholars through the ADVANCE Women of Color Summer Writing Retreat
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF ADVANCE Partnerships for Learning and Adaptation Networks - Institutions of Higher Education (PLAN-IHE) funding track is designed to expand the application of proven-successful gender-equity initiatives for STEM faculty through networked adaptation of a specific program or initiative.  Careful evaluation is expected to expand understanding of such initiatives   across institutions and institution types.

This project will adapt the Jackson State University (JSU) ADVANCE Summer Writing Retreat (SWR) to six other minority-serving institutions.  The resulting network will promote the scholarly activities of faculty women of color in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM).  The partner institutions include: 1) Tennessee State University, a public Historically Black College and University (HBCU); 2) Tougaloo College, a private HBCU in Mississippi; 3) The University of Texas, Pan American, a public Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI); 4) Norfolk State University, a public HBCU in Virginia; 5) Winston-Salem State University, a public HBCU in North Carolina; and 6) The University of the Virgin Islands, a public HBCU.  The objectives of this project are to: 1) Adapt components of the JSU ADVANCE SWR to six other minority-serving institutions; 2) Create a multi-institutional network that expands the resources that are available to faculty at the partner institutions; and 3) Develop a knowledge-building community that shares data and findings about the SWR adaptation process and the impact on scholarly productivity and career advancement.  The study will also contribute to better understanding of the career-life balance challenges among women of color in STEM faculty from a variety of minority serving institutions that serve African American, Hispanic, and Caribbean students, and can help inform the ways in which universities and other agencies plan to support diverse women of color in STEM disciplines.

This project will contribute a better understanding of the factors that contribute to, and those that inhibit the recruitment, retention, and advancement of women of color in STEM academic careers.  Uniquely, this project focuses on women of color faculty at HBCUs and HSIs.  This project will address well-documented challenges that women of color face in STEM related to scholarly productivity, publishing, securing of external grant funding, tenure, promotion into full professorships, and advancement into academic administrative leadership.  The project will shed light on the ways in which writing and collaboration communities (both face-to-face and online) can be useful tools in promoting scholarly productivity and work-life balance among women of color at minority serving institutions.  Through the adaptations, the objective is to learn which components of the SWR most effectively promote the participants' scholarly productivity while also giving attention to the role of scholarly identity and work-life balance in writing and research productivity among STEM faculty women of color. 

The Partnerships for Learning and Adaptation Networks program track supports projects that promote the adaptation and implementation of previously effective ADVANCE programs in new contexts and the testing of innovative strategies to promote the participation, success, and advancement of women in STEM academic careers.  PLAN projects also contribute to the knowledge base on gender equity in STEM academic careers.

PLAN-IHE: Expanding the Network of STEM Scholars through the

ADVANCE Summer Writing Retreat

 

The goal of the Expanding the Network of STEM Scholars through the ADVANCE Summer Writing Retreat (SWR) was to expand the successful Jackson State University (JSU) ADVANCE SWR to six other minority serving institutions (MSI) for adaptation and to build an inter/multi-institutional network that promotes the scholarly activities of women of color faculty in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and social and behavioral sciences (SBS) disciplines. During the six-year (2016-2021) project period, a learning and adaptation network, led by JSU, was established with six partners to address the well-documented challenges women of color face in STEM as it relates to scholarly productivity, academic publishing, securing of external grant funding, tenure and promotion into full professorships and advancement into academic administrative leadership.

The establishment of the multi-institutional network of partners was a major outcome of this project.  Leveraging relationships between colleagues and connections with institutional leaders who shared similar interests in achieving greater diversity, equity, inclusion and overall support for women in STEM, we formed a network of partners who were eager to learn and adapt the JSU writing retreat model to fit their unique institutional needs.  Representing a mix of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) and Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI), public/private entities and prior ADVANCE grantees, the collaborating institutions of higher education within the network along with the dates on which they hosted their initial adaptations of the JSU writing retreat are listed below:  

  • The University of Texas, Rio Grande Valley, a public HSI; May 22-28, 2016
  • The University of the Virgin Islands, a public HBCU; May 15-21, 2016
  • Norfolk State University, a public HBCU in Virginia; May 21-27, 2017
  • Tennessee State University, a public HBCU; June 11-17, 2017
  • Tougaloo College, a private HBCU in Mississippi; May 20-26, 2018
  • Winston-Salem State University, a public HBCU in North Carolina; June 3-9, 2018.

In addition to the implementation of these co-hosted, in-person summer writing groups, another relevant outcome of the multi-institutional collaboration was the initiation of a series of Virtual Summer Writing Groups.  Building off of the modifications made to the JSU writing retreat model, considering feedback from participants, and external evaluator?s recommendations for project improvement, we hosted several Online Writing Groups in 2019, which served as a perfect pilot run for the shift that we had to make during the final 2-years of the project when in-person writing retreats were cancelled due to Covid-19 travel restrictions.  In total, the following series of virtual writing groups were offered throughout the network:

  • JSU Hosted Multi-Institutional Summer Writing Group, 2019  
  • UTRGV Institution Specific Summer Writing Retreat, 2019
  • JSU Hosted Multi-Institutional Summer Writing Groups, 2020 ? Retreat was open to faculty from all partner institutions in the network.  Writing groups participants were organized into sub-groups based on the type of project they were developing: Grant Proposal, Journal Article (revise and resubmit), or Tenure and Promotion Narratives.  Using Zoom as a meeting platform, the groups met collectively to discuss self-care strategies and resources for maintaining balance and wellness during Covid-19, prior to navigating into break-out groups to share progress made during the week and plans for writing accountability for the upcoming week.
  • JSU Hosted Multi-Institutional Fall Writing Accountability Groups, 2020 ? Bi-weekly meetings were scheduled to follow-up on writing projects and research activities launched during the summer.  According to evaluator?s findings, these fall 2020 groups were also valuable sites for social-emotional support and community when everyone was isolated from traditional on-campus communities. 
  • JSU Hosted Data Science for Social and Environmental Justice Webinar Series, 2021
  • JSU Hosted Topic Specific Writing and Research Development Group, Summer 2021 ? This Data Science for Social Impact Writing and Research Development Group, allowed for women in STEM and SBS disciplines from across the network of partner institutions to connect and explore strategies for building their data science teaching, research, and collaborative networks. 

In each writing group, 12-16 women in STEM received training in strategies for increasing their writing productivity resulting in over 150 women gaining exposure to the JSU intervention.  Additionally, institutional leaders and an implementation team from each of the 6-partner institutions received training in how to plan and implement successful writing groups at their home institutions.  After hosting their initial writing groups with support from the JSU leadership team, three of the six partner institutions have since launched faculty writing groups as part of their ongoing faculty development initiatives.  JSU is also using the model as part of their new faculty development program.   

 

For additional details on how the multi-institutional network was formed and how the writing retreat intervention was transferred to our partners, see Wheaton, D. & Moore, L. (2019). Creating a multi-institutional writing retreat network: How we did it and why it works. The Journal of Faculty Development, 33(2), 97-102.
